fields.name: 2002 KL6
fields.information: (154244) 2002 KL6, is an Amor-class NEO, which means it's not on an Earth-crossing orbit and has an orbit larger than that of the Earth. Amor asteroids approach the orbit of Earth from beyond, but do not cross its orbit. Most Amors cross the orbit of Mars. It will still be coming close enough to us to get radar observations and several astronomical observatories are gearing up for that.
fields.teaser: If we were on Mars this asteroid would get dangerously close to us.

fields.name: 2010 NY65
fields.information:
2010 NY65 is an Aten-class NEO, so it's on an Earth-crossing orbit that is smaller than the Earth's orbit, which is somewhat rare for an NEO. This NEO is also a NHATS (Near-Earth Object Human Space Flight Accessible Targets Study) target-of-opportunity, so one day people could travel to it!

The above video was produced by the Goldstone Radar Observing team

This asteroid makes yearly close approaches to Earth from 2015 to 2022 that make it an excellent candidate for detecting Yarkovsky effect if radar ranging measurements occur over multiple close encounters spanning at least several years. If successful, detection of the orbital drift due to the Yarkovsky effect can yield an estimate of the asteroid's mass.
fields.teaser: The path of this asteroid crosses Earth's orbit. It could also be a destination for space travellers in the future.
